sen.j: 道興（どうこう、永享2年（1430年） - 大永7年1527年）は、室町時代の僧侶で聖護院門跡。
sen.e: Doko (1430 - 1527) was a Buddhist monk who was monzeki (chief priest who is a member of the Imperial family) of Shogo-in Temple in the Muromachi period.
Doko (1430 - 1527) was a Buddhist monk who was the monzeki (chief priest who is a member of the Imperial Family) of Shogo-in Temple during the Muromachi period.
Doko (1430 - 1527) was a Buddhist monk who was the monzeki (chief priest who is a member of the Imperial Family) of Shogo-in Temple during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 関白近衛房嗣（摂政・関白の一覧 1445年 - 1447年）の子。
sen.e: He was a son of Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Fusatsugu KONOE (list of Sessho (regent) and Kanpaku during 1445 - 1447).
He was a son of Fusatsugu KONOE (list of Sessho (regents), who was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) from 1445 to 1447.
He was a son of Fusatsugu KONOE (list of Sessho (regents), who was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) from 1445 to 1447.

sen.j: 兄弟に近衛教基、近衛政家。
sen.e: Norimoto KONOE and Masaie KONOE were his brothers.
Norimoto KONOE and Masaie KONOE were his brothers.
Norimoto KONOE and Masaie KONOE were his brothers.

sen.j: 1465年（寛正6年）に准三宮宣下を受ける。
sen.e: In 1465, he was conferred the title of Junsangu (honorary title next to the three empresses) by the Imperial proclamation.
In 1465, he was conferred the title of Junsangu (honorary title next to the three empresses) by Imperial proclamation.
In 1465, he was conferred the title of Junsangu (honorary title next to the three empresses) by Imperial proclamation.

sen.j: 1486年（文明 (日本)18年）・1487年（文明19年）に書いた東 (曖昧さ回避)の紀行『廻国雑記』が有名。
sen.e: "Kaikoku Zakki", a record of his travels in eastern provinces written in 1486 and 1487, is well-known.
"Kaikoku Zakki," a record of his travels in eastern provinces written in 1486 and 1487, is well known.
